facts.text: The appellant was plying a bus between Jaipur and Ajmer on a permit granted to him for three years by resolution of the Regional Transport Authority, Jaipur, dated December 16/17, 1958.
In August, 1960, the State Government promulgated rules under s. 68A of the Act, called the Rajasthan State Road Transport Services Development Rules, 1960.
A draft scheme was published on September 7, 1960, for taking over the Jaipur-Ajmer route.
The appellant made objections to the draft scheme within the time allowed by the notification thereof.
The State Government appointed the Legal Remembrancer to hear and decide the objections under r. 7 of the Rules.

An application was made under Art. 226 by some bus operators before the Rajasthan High Court challenging the constitutionality of s. 68-D of the Act and the legality of the Rules; dismissed on November 9, 1960, holding officer cannot cancel draft scheme.
On November 21, 1960, application before officer to permit appellant to give evidence on points of fact; rejected on ground no provision in Rules for recording evidence.
On November 23, 1960, another application to lead evidence to show draft scheme must be rejected; rejected, officer bound by Rajasthan High Court decision.
Officer approved the draft scheme by order dated December 7, 1960, after hearing arguments.
On January 9, 1961, Regional Transport Authority informed appellant that his permit was cancelled as from January 26, 1961, or later.
Appellant moved Rajasthan High Court unsuccessfully; prayer for leave to appeal rejected; special leave granted by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the officer hearing objections under s. 68-D(2) has power to reject the draft scheme in its entirety and withhold approval.
Whether the hearing under s. 68-D(2) includes taking of evidence, oral or documentary, or is confined to arguments.

petitioner_arguments.text: The officer was wrong in holding that he had no power to reject the draft scheme in its entirety.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 68-D(2) of Motor Vehicles Act; r. 7(6) of Rules

petitioner_arguments.text: The officer was wrong in holding that he could not take evidence, oral or documentary, and hearing under s. 68-D(2) was only arguments.

respondent_arguments.text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General did not contest that under s. 68-D(2) and r. 7(6), the officer has power to withhold approval.

court_reasoning.text: s. 68-D(2) provides that State Government may approve or modify the scheme, which implies power not to approve at all; 'may approve' includes 'may not approve'; draft scheme is proposal until approved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officer wrong in holding no power to reject scheme, influenced by Rajasthan HC; r. 7(6) same as s. 68-D(2)

court_reasoning.text: Hearing under s. 68-D(2) before quasi-judicial authority; purpose to verify if scheme provides efficient etc. service; may require evidence, oral or documentary, if necessary and relevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hearing not merely arguments; officer controls evidence production; cited Gullapalli Nageswara Rao for quasi-judicial nature.

court_reasoning.text: Officer's wrong approach on both points vitiated the hearing; approval set aside.

holdings.text: Under s. 68-D(2), authority may approve, modify, or not approve draft scheme at all.
Hearing under s. 68-D(2) may include taking relevant evidence, oral or documentary, subject to control by authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: State Government acts as quasi-judicial tribunal under s. 68-D

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajasthan High Court decision in writ petition
precedents_cited.relevance: Held officer cannot cancel draft scheme; overruled implicitly

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Framing, approval of schemes by State Transport Undertaking; hearing of objections; power to approve/modify/not approve

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition challenging s. 68D and Rules

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan State Road Transport Services Development Rules, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Hearing objections; interpreted consistent with s. 68-D(2)

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order approving scheme set aside; draft scheme to be reconsidered by officer after proper hearing including observations on powers and evidence; writ petition dismissed; appellant gets costs from State of Rajasthan.
outcome.relief_granted: Scheme approval quashed; remand for fresh hearing
outcome.costs: Appellant gets costs from State of Rajasthan

key_quotes.text: 'may approve or modify the scheme' clearly implies... power also... not to approve the scheme at all... 'may approve' on a reasonable interpretation include 'may not approve'.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on power to reject draft scheme under s. 68-D(2)

key_quotes.text: A hearing before a quasi-judicial authority does not merely mean an argument it may in proper cases include the taking of evidence, both oral and documentary.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of hearing under s. 68-D(2)
